utterances: Well, as it seems with everything these days, it all goes back to this global credit crunch that we're in the midst of.
Back in June, Home Depot agreed to sell its construction supply unit to a group of private equity firms, including Bain Capital and the Carlyle Group.
And the price they agreed on at the time was $10.3 billion.
Now, the way these deals work is that the private equity firms borrow money from investment banks who then repackage those loans and sell them to investors in the form of bonds.
And as you know, in the last few months the demand for any kind of debt that isn't backed by the federal government has really fallen off because of the subprime mortgage meltdown.
And investment banks have become wary of taking on that kind of debt for fear they'll get stuck with it.
So reports say to keep them from walking away from the deal, Home Depot agreed to cut the sale price by 18 percent and to guarantee some of the debt used to fund the deal.
So does this mean that the private equity boom might be dead?
Well, not entirely, according to one professor I spoke to.
Andrew Metrick teaches finance at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.
He says these private equity firms have raised billions of dollars and keep raising it.
For example, the Blackstone Group recently closed the biggest buyout fund in history - more than $21 billion.
And Metrick says the terms may change but the buying spree isn't over.
There's a tremendous amount of the equity capital that the private equity folks control now.
And there's an awful a lot of companies out there for them to buy.
What it means now is that the price that they're going to be willing to pay and the amount of leverage that they're going to be able to put on the deals is going to be lower.
You know, some see the Home Depot deal as a sort of bellwether.
There are an estimated $400 billion worth of buyout deals that are in the pipeline right now.
And some analysts predict more companies are going to have to accept lower prices and make other concessions.
And so what does all of this mean for Home Depot?
Well, Home Depot has been wanting to sell this division to focus on its core retail business.
But the sale was also meant to fund a $22.5 billion stock buyback program.
And so analysts say the company was really anxious to get this deal done, even at a discount.
Thank you so much, Amy.
Amy Scott of public radio's daily business show, MARKTETPLACE, which is produced by American Public Media.
Now to the Supreme Court, where this morning protesters had a message for the newest justice.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Chanting) Hey, hey, ho, ho, Kavanaugh has got to go.
Hey, hey, ho, ho, Kavanaugh has got to go.
Only days after the Senate voted narrowly to confirm him, Brett Kavanaugh made his first appearance on the high court bench.
NPR national justice correspondent Carrie Johnson was watching the oral arguments, and she's here now to tell us about them.
Hey, Carrie.
Hi, Mary Louise.
So we heard the protesters outside the court.
What was it like inside today?

Well, there were really a number of reasons why we thought that it was appropriate to have the conference now, to have it in New York City, and to have it in a way that it involved voices other than the usual voices we hear today in academia, in policy circles, and in the media.
(End of soundbite)
Right.
And Harry Reid, whatever he did, he's not up for reelection next year.
The Democrat - a lot of Republicans are trying to tie their Democratic opponents to Harry Reid.
But, one, we're not really sure what Harry Reid did other than failing to file on a profit (unintelligible).
It's not like a corruption case.
But, again, it's too soon to say what's going to happen with that.

Now as we enter the home-stretch of this election season, both Republicans and Democrats are directing some of their party's funds tactically, moving some away from races that were previously competitive and into races that are suddenly competitive.
To tell us more, we're joined now by Sheila Krumholz, the acting director of the Center for Responsive Politics.
And she's been kind enough to come and join us here in Studio 3A.
Thanks very much for being with us today.
Thanks for having me.
And let's start with the Republicans.
The New York Times said the GOP was pulling out of the Ohio's Senate race.
RNC Chair Ken Mehlman says they're not.
Who's right?
Well, it sounds like they're putting in some money, but not as much as they could and certainly not as much as Senator DeWine would like them to put in.
But this is now a race that is called Democratic leaning, something that would have been unheard of, to think of, just a few short weeks ago.
So DeWine joins Santorum and Chafee as the underdogs, which is again just adding to the list that you were discussing previously about surprising - how quickly fortunes change.
Can you gauge from where the parties send or pull out money whether they have in fact given up on, for example, Max Baucus, the Republican senator in Montana?
Conrad Burns.
Excuse me.
Conrad Burns, excuse me.
Thank you.
That's why he's here, you know - the information otherwise.
Anyway, and Lincoln Chafee - I got that right - in Rhode Island?
Right.
Well, unfortunately, we as watchdogs on the money are always kind of hamstringed by the reporting deadlines.
And so unfortunately we're not going be able to see exactly where the money goes in the 11th hour until well after the election.

But we do know that these dollars that go in at the end can be critical for taking advantage of late-breaking opportunities and for the Democrats for nailing that majority in the few races they absolutely need to get.
And as you look at patterns, what can you derive from what you see?
Well, what we're seeing is what we've heard all year, and that is that the Democrats are having schisms at the top in their strategy, not in agreement.
The DNC and Dean is arguing with Emanuel and Schumer, chairs of the DCCC, the Democratic Congressional and the Senatorial Campaign Committees, about how they should strategize during this final push.
And it sounds like there is - they're feeling the heat and not able to direct the money in a kind of cohesive way in the same way that the Republicans have done for so long.

In other words, the chairs of the Congressional Campaign Committees and the Senatorial Campaign Committees want to say let's send all the money to this seat that we can win or this state where we can win a Senate seat.

As opposed to Howard Dean, the chairman of the party, who says we've got to build the party structure up in states where we have virtually vanished as a political institution, so we can battle not just this year but in the years ahead.
Right.
And this is a bad time to be having - struggling with these decisions.
I mean those should have been strategized long ago.
As opposed to three weeks before Election Day.
Ken?
Back to the Ohio Senate race.
There was a lot of head scratching in Washington over that New York Times story that the Republican were pulling out.
If Mike DeWine loses in Ohio, and it looks like he will lose in Ohio, it's not because of money.
The political climate, as you know, is just awful for the Republicans there.
DeWine has a big financial lead over the Democratic nominee, Sherrod Brown.
So it's not because of money.

But what I thought was interesting is how money - we were talking about the Virginia Senate race a while ago, and even though George Allen kept tripping over his own mouth and own words, everybody kept saying, well Jim Webb is not getting the money.
But since that incident, since the macaca incident, since Allen's, you know, various missteps, a lot of money has come into Jim Webb's campaign.
As a matter of fact, I think in the last quarter he has raised as much money as George Allen.
Allen probably has more now, but money seems to be attracted to winners or perceived winners.
And if the Democrats are perceived to either winning the House, which they could do, and coming close to wining the Senate, then the money will go their way, and that's what seems to be happening.
Here's an e-mail question we got from Jason in Vancouver, Washington.
There was an article in The Wall Street Journal today that mentioned that money doesn't seem to be helping Republicans as much this year as it has helped the incumbents in the past.
Are there races that are impervious to money this year?
Is funding less important than issues, or am I being naïve?
Sheila Krumholz, what do you think?
Money is always a critical factor, but it is never the only factor.
You also need to have good campaign organization, name recognition, campaign skills.
And in this cycle in particular, you know, a scandal can eject you from the lineup very quickly.
So that isn't the case I think with Allen.
He's had a lot of missteps and the personal financial disclosure, the lack of disclosure of options at a couple of companies on which he sat on their board, was just another one in a long list.
So that - it isn't one issue that happened there, but it's enough for the DNC to take out a loan, a line of credit for sending some last-minute dollars toward the VA race.

And, Ken, we were talking last week when we were in Ohio with the vice chair of the Republican National Committee who points out money really helps with those Get Out the Vote efforts that were so crucial to Republicans in 2004 and that they hope to duplicate this year.
That's right.
It can't pay for enthusiasm, and we don't know how enthusiastic the Republican base will be.
But it can produce the kind of organizations that if they can get out to vote, the money will help.
Sheila Krumholz, thanks very much for being with us today.
I appreciate your time to come in.
Well that's a great state to talk about money, because it's a very expensive media market.
You have to pay for not only - you have to pay for New York TV and Philadelphia TV in the south.
So you have to have a lot of money.
Bob Menendez, the appointed Democratic incumbent, has a far bigger financial advantage over the Republican Tom Kean Jr. Kean of course has the name, the magic name.
And the Republicans…
Definitely, yeah.
…and the Republican Party is spending more money on it.
But I think that even though the Republicans were hopeful this was going be the seat they were going to pick up, I think Menendez is starting to pull ahead.
Tom Kean has called for the resignation of Speaker Dennis Hastert.
He's called for the resignation of Defense Secretary Rumsfeld.
You wonder if he's trying to reach out to more and more moderates.
And if that's the case, then conservative Republicans may say, why show up if Kean is going to be no different than Menendez?
Well, yeah, In New Jersey, I mean a Republican might as well be a Democrat anywhere else in the country.
And as you well know, no Republican has been elected to the Senate from New Jersey since 1972.
Oh, I didn't know it was that long.
Yeah, Ken knows.
Amy, thanks very much for the phone call.
Thank you.
We're talking to our Political Junkie, NPR's political editor Ken Rudin.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's get another caller.
This will be Greg.
Greg's for this from Burlington, North Carolina.
Hi, good afternoon.
What a wonderful show, as usual.
